Api Controller

Every controller must extend this class. List of properties which are available

model: DinoModel
It represents model data and validation errors for the request. It is used along with @Parse(). Here we have a complete example.
request: Express.Request
Expressjs request object is mapped to this property.
response: Express.Response
Expressjs response object is mapped to this property.
next: Express.NextFunction
Expressjs next handler is mapped to this property.
dino: DinoResponse

dino property has two methods proceed() and throw() explained below

1. proceed(result: any)

When results are returned after async-callback operation, you would then like to have your result available to the next middlewares in the chain, say your result filters and ResponseEnd middlewares. Here is how you do it:


        

        
    
            
  • 
                this.next is highly discouraged to use.
            
    • 
            
  • 
                Invoking
                this.next() proceeds the execution to the next dinoware but results are not captured. If results are
                to be captured and proceeded use
                this.dino.proceed(result).
            
    • 
        

        
2. throw(err: Error)

        

            this.dino.throw is responsible to proceed errors to the next error middlewares in the chain when error
            is encountered in async-callback operation. Following example explains one such example of mongo connection error.

        

            

        

        
    
            
  • 
                MongoClient is an external npm package to install.
    • 
            
  • 
                this.next(new MongoConnectException()) or
                this.dino.throw(new MongoConnectException()) both essentially does the same, you can pick your own
                choice.
            
    • 
            
  • 
                The exception will be caught by
                MongoConnectExceptionFilter which is declared on controller and ends the response with 500 status
                code.
            
    • 
        

    






    

        
        Remember
    

    
    
        
  • 
            The request and response properties depends purely on express.js version you have installed.
        
    • 
        
  • 
            To handle exceptions on application level use
            ServerError middlewares.
        
    • 
        
  • 
            We suggest you to use
            this.dino.throw over
            this.next for better consistence and readability.
        
    •
